title: Jack Hemi
text:
Jack Raharuhi Hemi (23 August 1914 – 1 June 1996) was a New Zealand freezing worker, rugby union and league player, shearer. Of <a href="M%C4%81ori%20people">Māori</a> descent, he identified with the <a href="Ngati%20Kahungunu">Ngati Kahungunu</a> and <a href="Rangitane">Rangitane</a> <a href="iwi">iwi</a>. He was born in <a href="Te%20Poho-o-Tutawake">Te Poho-o-Tutawake</a>, <a href="Wairarapa">Wairarapa</a>, New Zealand on 23 August 1914.
Early years.
Jack Hemi was the oldest son of Hineipikitia-ki-te-rangi (Piki) Reiri, of Te Whiti, and her husband, Paraikete (Blanket) Hēmi. There were thirteen children in the family. Hemi attended Te Whiti School. He worked at a freezing works and, when his father died in 1936, Hemi assumed responsibility for his mother and four siblings.
Rugby union career.
Hemi played <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> for the Gladstone club before moving to the Featherston club and first represented <a href="Wairarapa%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Wairarapa</a> in 1933, aged only 18. He played for <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand Māori</a> in 1934 and toured Australia with the team in 1935. He was also an All Blacks trialist in 1935.
Rugby league career.
In 1936 Hemi switched codes, joining the new <a href="Manukau%20Magpies">Manukau</a> <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> club in the <a href="Auckland%20Rugby%20League">Auckland Rugby League</a> competition. He represented <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> that year against <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> and also played for <a href="Auckland%20rugby%20league%20team">Auckland</a>. He represented <a href="New%20Zealand%20M%C4%81ori%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand Māori</a> in 1937, being part of the team that defeated <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> 16–5 at <a href="Carlaw%20Park">Carlaw Park</a>.
He toured Australia in 1938, slotting a goal against <a href="Queensland%20rugby%20league%20team">Queensland</a> from 17 yards behind the halfway line. Hemi toured Great Britain in 1939, but World War II ended the tour without a test match being played. Exempt from War duty Hemi continued to play for Manukau. In <a href="1941%20Auckland%20Rugby%20League%20season">1941</a> he scored 206 points for Manukau in all competition matches which was comfortably a record in Auckland Rugby League senior football to that point. He scored 12 tries, and kicked 59 conversions along with 26 penalties during the season.
In 1945 he represented <a href="Wellington%20rugby%20league%20team">Wellington</a> alongside his younger brother, Lou.
